questions.text: A 4-hour-old male newborn has perioral discoloration for the past several minutes. Oxygen by nasal cannula does not improve the cyanosis. He was delivered by cesarean delivery at 37 weeks' gestation to a 38-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2. Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus that was well-controlled during the pregnancy. She has not received any immunizations since her childhood. The newborn's temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 55/min, and blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 85%. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a 2/6 holosystolic murmur along the lower left sternal border. The abdomen is soft and non-tender. Echocardiography shows pulmonary arteries arising from the posterior left ventricle, and the aorta rising anteriorly from the right ventricle. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Without treatment, transposition of the great vessels is fatal. If the disease is allowed to follow its natural course, the mortality rate within the first year alone is about 90%.

B) CORRECT:

TGA results in rapidly worsening hypoxemia and cyanosis shortly after birth, and relies on a patent ductus arteriosus. The ductus arteriosus is kept patent in fetal circulation by the effect of low partial pressure of oxygen in fetal circulation, as well as by endogenously produced prostaglandin E. After birth, the ductus arteriosus begins to close in response to an increase in the partial pressure of oxygen. Intravenously administered prostaglandin E1 keeps the ductus arteriosus open and allows mixing of blood between the pulmonary and systemic circulation. This effect is crucial for initial survival of infants with TGA because it is the only way to maintain oxygenation of the arterial blood until surgical repair can be performed.
Image Description:

In transposition of the great vessels, deoxygenated blood enters the systemic circulation. Survival after birth is only possible via an intracardiac shunt (e.g., across a patent ductus arteriosus and/or a patent foramen ovale). The shunt diverts oxygenated blood from the pulmonary circulation into the systemic circulation (white arrows).

C) INCORRECT:

The ductus arteriosus is kept patent in fetal circulation by the low partial pressure of oxygen in fetal circulation, as well as by endogenously produced prostaglandin E. Indomethacin, a nonselective cyclooxygenase inhibitor, closes the ductus arteriosus by decreasing prostaglandin synthesis. Because a patent ductus arteriosus is vital for this newborn's survival, administering indomethacin would be a grave mistake.

D) INCORRECT:

An arterial switch operation is required in all neonates with transposition of the great arteries. This procedure is usually delayed for 2–3 days until the high pulmonary vascular resistance of fetal circulation decreases. A different therapeutic measure is required immediately to maintain a patent ductus arteriosus while preparations for surgery are made.

E) INCORRECT:

A CT angiography is not indicated in this newborn with transposition of the great vessels because it would not alter the clinical management and echocardiography has already confirmed the diagnosis.
questions.hint: Echocardiography findings are consistent with the diagnosis of transposition of the great arteries (TGA): In TGA, the systemic circulation is disconnected from pulmonary circulation and venous blood that is received by the right ventricle is pumped to the rest of the body without being oxygenated. TGA is more commonly associated with infants born to diabetic mothers.

questions.text: A 3-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician because his mother has noticed that he tires easily and sweats while feeding. During the past week, she has noticed that his lips and nails turn blue while crying. He was born at 35 weeks' gestation and weighed 2100 g (4 lb 10 oz); he currently weighs 2300 g (5 lb 1 oz). His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 168/min, respirations are 63/min, and blood pressure is 72/42 mm Hg. Examination shows a 3/6 systolic ejection murmur heard over the left upper sternal border. A single S2 is present. Echocardiography confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following factors is most responsible for this patient's cyanosis?

choices.text: Degree of right ventricular outflow obstruction
Degree of left ventricular outflow obstruction

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH) is one of the four features of TOF, it is not the main determinant of cyanosis. RVH is a compensatory mechanism against the outflow tract obstruction, which helps to reduce cyanosis by increasing flow through the stenotic pulmonary vasculature so that deoxygenated blood does not flow through the VSD and into the systemic circulation. However, RVH can only compensate to a small degree to improve normal circulatory flow and is, therefore, only a minor determinant of cyanosis.

B) CORRECT:

In patients with TOF, the right ventricular (RV) outflow obstruction due to central pulmonary valve stenosis and hypoplasia determines the severity of cyanosis and the intensity of the systolic heart murmur. Blood preferentially flows via the path of least resistance. When there is a high degree of RV outflow obstruction, blood will flow through the VSD instead of through the pulmonary artery for oxygenation in the lungs. As a result, deoxygenated blood will enter the left ventricle via the VSD and be pumped into the aorta and systemic circulation. If there is minimal RV outflow obstruction, blood will flow through the pulmonary vasculature, and become oxygenated before reaching the left ventricle, resulting in a reduction of cyanosis. In TOF, the single S2 can result from an attenuated pulmonary component (P2) that is often not heard on auscultation.

Older children with TOF tend to squat during spells of hypoxia, which relieves symptoms by increasing systemic vascular resistance and, in turn, left ventricular outflow resistance. This creates higher left ventricular pressures, so that blood in the right ventricle will be directed through the pulmonary vasculature rather than the VSD. The increased blood flow across the RV outflow obstruction during squatting is also associated with an increased intensity of the ejection murmur.
Image Description:

Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)

The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

C) INCORRECT:

A ventricular septal defect (VSD) is one of the four features of TOF but it is not the main determinant of cyanosis. Rather, it is the pressure differences across the VSD that determine the degree of cyanosis. Specifically, higher right ventricular pressures and/or lower left ventricular pressures are associated with increased right-to-left shunting and, thus, with increased cyanosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Although an overriding aorta is one of the four features of TOF, it is not the main determinant of cyanosis. In patients with TOF, the aorta is displaced to the right ventricle, over the VSD, allowing blood from both ventricles to be pumped into the aorta. This causes deoxygenated blood to enter the systemic circulation, contributing to cyanosis. However, another factor has a greater impact on the degree of cyanosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Atrial septal defect (ASD) is not one of the four features of TOF. However, in a patient with TOF, the presence of a concomitant ASD could lead to greater right-to-left shunting and thus exacerbate cyanosis.
Image Description:

An atrial septal defect causes blood to flow from the left to the right atrium (left-to-right shunt; white arrow), resulting in volume overload of the right atrium and ventricle (1). As a result, there is dilation and compensatory hypertrophy (double-headed white arrows) of the right atrium and ventricle (2). In the late stages, Eisenmenger syndrome with shunt reversal (right-to-left shunt; white arrow) and cyanosis can occur (3).

Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

F) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular outflow obstruction (e.g., aortic stenosis) is not one of the four features of TOF. However, if aortic stenosis (or any form of increased left ventricular outflow resistance) was present, this would decrease right-to-left shunting by creating higher left-sided pressures and thus reduce, rather than increase, cyanosis.
questions.hint: The presence of intermittent cyanosis, fatigue, and sweating during periods of exertion in a neonate with a systolic ejection murmur over the left upper sternal border and a single S2 is suggestive of tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

questions.text: A 4-day-old male infant is brought to the physician because of respiratory distress and bluish discoloration of his lips and tongue. He was born at term and the antenatal period was uncomplicated. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 65/min, and blood pressure is 70/46 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 82%. A grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur is heard over the left lower sternal border. A single S2 that does not split with respiration is present. Echocardiography shows defects in the interatrial and interventricular septae, as well as an imperforate muscular septum between the right atrium and right ventricle. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Increased pulmonary vascular markings on chest x-ray
Weak pulses in the femoral arteries

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased pulmonary vascular markings on chest x-ray due to pulmonary vascular congestion is seen in certain cyanotic congenital heart defects such as transposition of the great arteries (TGA), which would manifest with postnatal cyanosis, tachypnea, and a single loud S2. However, echocardiography revealed tricuspid atresia, in which pulmonary blood flow and thus pulmonary vascular markings are decreased because of the concomitant pulmonary outflow tract obstruction.

In approximately 25% of cases of tricuspid valve atresia, no pulmonary stenosis is present. In these patients, the presence of a large, nonrestrictive ventricular septal defect (VSD) or a concomitant TGA may result in increased pulmonary blood flow and increased pulmonary markings. However, in those cases, auscultation would reveal a wide split S2.
Image Description:

TGV is a cyanotic congenital heart disease in which the pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle and the aorta from the right ventricle, resulting in the formation of parallel circulatory systems. The left ventricle pumps oxygenated blood into the pulmonary circulation (red) and the right ventricle pumps deoxygenated blood into the aorta (blue), resulting in cyanosis.

TGV is fatal unless a shunt between the two circulations is present (i.e., a patent ductus arteriosus or a patent foramen ovale) or a surgical intervention is performed in the neonatal period.

B) INCORRECT:

Tracheal bowing and narrowing on an x-ray is characteristic of a double aortic arch, which may manifest with cyanosis and tachypnea due to respiratory distress among newborns as a result of tracheal compression. However, patients would usually have stridor on examination. A double aortic arch would not explain the holosytolic murmur, the single S2, or the echocardiographic findings.
Image Description:

Ventral view of mediastinal structures

There is constriction of the trachea and esophagus as a result of the additional aortic arch (vascular ring anomaly).

C) CORRECT:

In TVA, blood is unable to pass from the right atrium (RA) to the right ventricle (RV). Consequently, the RV is almost always hypoplastic. Venous blood, therefore, passes from the RA via an atrial septal defect (which, under these circumstances, is essential for survival) to the left atrium, where it mixes with oxygenated blood from the lungs. The mixed blood is pumped from the left ventricle (LV) into the systemic circulation (resulting in cyanosis) and pulmonary circulation (via a patent ductus arteriosus). LV hypertrophy occurs because the LV is single-handedly pumping blood through both the pulmonary and systemic circulation. A combination of RV hypoplasia and LV hypertrophy results in a severe left-axis deviation. Other findings that may be present on ECG include tall P waves (due to right atrial enlargement) and small R waves in the right precordial leads (e.g., V1, V2).

The majority of patients with TVA also have a ventricular septal defect (VSD) and concomitant pulmonary outflow obstruction. The systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border arises from a VSD. In a patient with TVA, a single S2 that does not split with respiration indicates severely limited blood flow across the pulmonary valve and/or severe pulmonary stenosis. The systolic murmur of a VSD is softer with increasing severity of pulmonary stenosis and/or increasing size of the defect, because both result in a decreased pressure gradient across the VSD. Prostaglandin-E1 is given to maintain PDA patency (thereby increasing pulmonary circulation and blood oxygenation), but definitive treatment is staged surgical repair.
Image Description:

AA: ascending aorta
PT: pulmonary trunk
PV: pulmonary valve
RA: right atrium
SVC: superior vena cava
TV: tricuspid valve

D) INCORRECT:

Elf-like features (e.g., small chin, broad forehead, hypertelorism, a depressed nasal bridge, anteverted nares) are seen in patients with Williams syndrome, which is typically associated with supravalvular aortic stenosis. Severe supravalvular aortic stenosis may result in hypotension and a systolic murmur. However, the systolic murmur is best heard at the right upper sternal border, and cyanosis would not be present. In addition, echocardiography would reveal evidence of aortic stenosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Weak femoral artery pulsations are seen in patients with coarctation of the aorta, for which there is no evidence (e.g., forward diastolic flow, narrowing of the aortic lumen) in this patient. In neonates, severe coarctation of the aorta can result in cyanosis (due to a right-to-left shunt via a patent ductus arteriosus) but cyanosis would only be present in the lower limbs and trunk (differential cyanosis); the upper limbs, lips, and face would appear normal.
Image Description:

(1) Hypoplasia of aorta can lead to hypertension (↑ BP) in the head and upper limbs as well as poststenotic hypoperfusion. In patent ductus arteriosus, this can be compensated by a right-to-left-shunt of blood from the pulmonary arteries into the aorta, resulting in the flow of mixed blood with decreased oxygen saturation (↓ SaO2) to the general circulation.

(2) After closure of the ductus arteriosus, the right-to-left shunt is absent (~ SaO2) and there is hypoperfusion (↓ BP) of the abdominal organs and lower extremities with oxygenated blood.

F) INCORRECT:

A delta wave on ECG (slurred R upstroke) is characteristic of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW). Ebstein anomaly is the congenital heart disease that is most frequently associated with WPW. Ebstein anomaly can also manifest with right atrial enlargement, atrial septal defect (ASD), holosystolic murmur (due to tricuspid regurgitation), and neonatal cyanosis (due to mixing of blood through the ASD). However, a wide split S2 is typically present in Ebstein anomaly, not a single S2. Moreover, Ebstein anomaly is classically associated with fetal lithium or benzodiazepine exposure, of which there is no history here (e.g., a maternal history of bipolar disorder). The absence of a tricuspid valve on echocardiography indicates a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

In the Ebstein anomaly, the tricuspid valve is displaced into the lumen of the right ventricle, resulting in atrialization of the right ventricle. The remaining ventricle is small and hypocontractile. Because tricuspid valve regurgitation is also usually present, there is retrograde flow in the right atrium, which is dilated by the volume overload, in addition to antegrade pulmonary blood flow. Blood flows through the patent foramen ovale or (commonly associated) atrial septal defect from the right atrium to the left atrium (right-to-left shunt) and then via the left ventricle into the circulation, resulting in pronounced cyanosis. The pulmonary circulation system may also be perfused through blood from the aorta (via the ductus arteriosus).

G) INCORRECT:

Collateral circulation and tortuous dilation of the posterior intercostal arteries can result in notching of the ribs in patients with coarctation of the aorta, for which there is no evidence (e.g., forward diastolic flow, narrowing of the aortic lumen) in this patient. In neonates, severe coarctation of the aorta can result in cyanosis (due to a right-to-left shunt via a patent ductus arteriosus), but it would only be present in the lower limbs and trunk (differential cyanosis); the upper limbs, lips, and face would appear normal. Moreover, rib notching typically occurs in patients with long-standing coarctation of the aorta and is unusual before the age of 5 years.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

Focal indentation of the distal aortic arch is seen at the location of aortic coarctation (illustration). An additional finding is inferior rib notching (Roesler sign; examples indicated by arrowheads), which is produced by dilated intercostal arteries.

The figure-3 sign of coarctation (indicated by red line) is seen in this patient. It is produced by prestenotic dilatation of the aortic arch and left subclavian artery in combination with post-stenotic dilatation of the descending aorta. The presence of bilateral rib notching indicates that the coarctation is distal to the origin of both subclavian arteries.
questions.hint: In this cyanotic neonate, an imperforate atrioventricular septum in the right side confirms the diagnosis of tricuspid valve atresia (TVA).

questions.text: A 5-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because his lips turned blue for several minutes while playing earlier that evening. She reports that he has had similar episodes during feeding that resolved quickly. He was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. He is at the 25th percentile for length and below the 5th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 42/min, and blood pressure is 83/55 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 90%. During the examination, he sits calmly in his mother's lap. He appears well. The patient begins to cry when examination of his throat is attempted; his lips and fingers begin to turn blue. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Pulmonary vascular congestion on x-ray of the chest
Decreased blood pressure in both lower extremities
Anomalous pulmonary venous return on MR angiography

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary vascular congestion seen on chest x-ray is a sign of left heart failure, with subsequent “backing up” of blood into the pulmonary vasculature, leading to enlarged pulmonary vessels. Although this finding is classically associated with congestive heart failure in adults (especially in older individuals), some congenital cardiac defects can also cause this finding (e.g., truncus arteriosus, total anomalous pulmonary venous return). In TOF (the most likely diagnosis in this case), there is a right ventricular outflow obstruction, leading to decreased blood flow to the pulmonary vasculature. Chest x-ray would more likely show decreased pulmonary vascular markings and a classic boot-shaped heart.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased blood pressure in the lower extremities is characteristic of aortic coarctation, which manifests with differential cyanosis (e.g., of the lower extremities) rather than central cyanosis (e.g., blue lips and fingers) as seen in this patient. Moreover, aortic coarctation rarely causes hypoxemia; in the rare case of hypoxemia, it is usually mild. Finally, aortic coarctation causes chronic rather than episodic symptoms.
Image Description:

(1) Hypoplasia of aorta can lead to hypertension (↑ BP) in the head and upper limbs as well as poststenotic hypoperfusion. In patent ductus arteriosus, this can be compensated by a right-to-left-shunt of blood from the pulmonary arteries into the aorta, resulting in the flow of mixed blood with decreased oxygen saturation (↓ SaO2) to the general circulation.

(2) After closure of the ductus arteriosus, the right-to-left shunt is absent (~ SaO2) and there is hypoperfusion (↓ BP) of the abdominal organs and lower extremities with oxygenated blood.

C) CORRECT:

Right axis deviation on ECG is typically seen in patients with TOF due to right ventricular hypertrophy. The thickened myocardium in the right ventricle produces increased electrical activity, which shifts the axis of cardiac depolarization. TOF also involves an overriding aorta, ventricular septal defect, and pulmonary stenosis. It is the most common congenital cyanotic heart lesion. In addition to these ECG findings, a chest x-ray showing a boot-shaped heart also supports the diagnosis. Echocardiography confirms the diagnosis.
Image Description:

Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)

The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

D) INCORRECT:

A machine-like murmur over the heart is pathognomonic for patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). PDA is usually an acyanotic congenital condition because most blood passes through normal circulation and thus sufficient oxygen saturation is maintained; only a small amount of blood is pumped through the PDA. Symptoms can vary depending on the degree of patency but may include tachycardia, tachypnea, and poor growth. The infant described here is lagging behind in terms of weight gain, but vital signs are within the normal range for a 5-month old infant (HR 80–160/min, RR 30–60/min). Finally, PDA causes continuous symptoms, as opposed to the episodic symptoms described for this patient.
Image Description:

In patent ductus arteriosus, there is a left-to-right shunt, with blood flowing from the aorta to the pulmonary arteries during both systole and diastole (1). This shunt leads to volume overload (recirculation) of the blood within the pulmonary vessels, the left atrium, and left ventricle (2). Eventually, because of the increased blood flow to the pulmonary circulation, pulmonary hypertension may develop as well as Eisenmenger syndrome, which involves a shunt reversal. The left-to-right-shunt without cyanosis becomes a right-to-left shunt with cyanosis (3).

Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Pink: structures that contain mixed blood

E) INCORRECT:

Anomalous pulmonary venous return on MR angiography would be diagnostic of total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR). Although TAPVR is survivable and can cause central cyanosis in patients with a right-to-left shunt, symptoms are continuous rather than episodic, as seen here.
Image Description:

A congenital heart defect in which the pulmonary veins merge to form a connecting vein that drains into the systemic venous circulation (e.g., the vena cava) rather than the left atrium. Without return of blood to the left heart, there is no systemic circulation. Survival after birth depends on the presence of a right-to-left shunt (usually an atrial septal defect) to allow for blood to enter the left heart, then systemic circulation.

F) INCORRECT:

A diminutive left ventricle on echocardiogram is seen in hypoplastic left heart syndrome, which can also manifest with central cyanosis. However, the cyanosis would not be episodic (as in this patient) because the hypoplastic left heart would never be able to adequately perfuse the peripheral tissues.
questions.hint: The cyanotic episode described here is characteristic of the tet spells seen in tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

questions.text: One day after a 4700-g (10-lb 6-oz) male newborn is delivered to a 28-year-old primigravid woman, the newborn has bluish discoloration of the lips and fingernails. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 166/min, respirations are 63/min, and blood pressure is 68/44 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 81%. Examination shows central cyanosis. A grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur is heard over the left lower sternal border. A single second heart sound is present. Supplemental oxygen does not improve cyanosis. An x-ray of the chest shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette with a narrowed mediastinum. Further evaluation of the mother is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An increased serum TSH concentration suggests hypothyroidism. Subclinical maternal hypothyroidism can increase the risk for future cognitive impairment, but it is not associated with TGA.

B) INCORRECT:

Prenatal alcohol consumption can cause fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FASD). FASD can manifest with a wide range of cardiac abnormalities, including atrial septal defects, VSD, and great heart vessel defects. However, structural heart defects also typically manifest in combination with other more characteristic FASD findings, such as facial abnormalities (e.g., short palpebral fissures, thin vermillion border, smooth philtrum).

C) INCORRECT:

Prenatal phenytoin intake is associated with fetal hydantoin syndrome. Although cases of congenital heart defects have been reported with maternal phenytoin use, TGA is rare. Furthermore, fetal hydantoin syndrome manifests with nail hypoplasia, hypoplasia of the digits, and abnormal facial features, none of which is seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Prenatal lithium intake is associated with Ebstein anomaly. This anomaly has a wide range of clinical presentations, including congenital cyanosis from right-to-left shunting. Depending on the severity of the anomaly, patients can develop a holosystolic murmur (due to tricuspid regurgitation), as heard in this patient. However, chest x-ray shows a box-shaped heart (due to the severe right-sided cardiomegaly from hypertrophy), not the egg-on-a-string sign seen in this patient. Furthermore, lithium intake is not associated with TGA.
Image Description:

In the Ebstein anomaly, the tricuspid valve is displaced into the lumen of the right ventricle, resulting in atrialization of the right ventricle. The remaining ventricle is small and hypocontractile. Because tricuspid valve regurgitation is also usually present, there is retrograde flow in the right atrium, which is dilated by the volume overload, in addition to antegrade pulmonary blood flow. Blood flows through the patent foramen ovale or (commonly associated) atrial septal defect from the right atrium to the left atrium (right-to-left shunt) and then via the left ventricle into the circulation, resulting in pronounced cyanosis. The pulmonary circulation system may also be perfused through blood from the aorta (via the ductus arteriosus).

E) INCORRECT:

A positive rapid plasma reagin test suggests a diagnosis of maternal syphilis, which can infect the infant in utero. Most cases of early congenital syphilis are asymptomatic at birth; symptoms do not typically develop until 5 weeks of life. If symptomatic at birth, findings include hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, nasal discharge, generalized lymphadenopathy, skeletal abnormalities, and pemphigus syphiliticus, none of which are seen in this patient. TGA is not associated with congenital syphilis.

F) CORRECT:

TGA is a cyanotic heart condition that is associated with maternal diabetes (see “Commonly associated conditions and risk factors of cyanotic congenital heart defects” table). Mothers with untreated diabetes will have an elevated HbA1c. Other potential neonatal complications from maternal diabetes include macrosomia (seen in this patient), polycythemia, hypoglycemia, hypocalcemia, and respiratory distress syndrome.

Alprostadil (PGE1) can be administered to this patient to help maintain a patent ductus arteriosus, which allows some oxygenated blood from the pulmonary veins to enter the systemic circulation through the aorta. This is a temporizing measure; surgical correction is the definitive treatment.
Image Description:

In transposition of the great vessels, deoxygenated blood enters the systemic circulation. Survival after birth is only possible via an intracardiac shunt (e.g., across a patent ductus arteriosus and/or a patent foramen ovale). The shunt diverts oxygenated blood from the pulmonary circulation into the systemic circulation (white arrows).
questions.hint: Cyanosis shortly after birth that does not improve with supplemental oxygen and a chest x-ray with the classic egg-on-a-string appearance (i.e., an enlarged heart with narrowed mediastinum due to an overlapping aorta and pulmonary trunk) are suggestive of a diagnosis of transposition of the great arteries (TGA). The holosystolic murmur indicates a coexistent ventricular septal defect (VSD), which is critical for life, as it allows for the mixing of oxygenated blood and its entry into the systemic circulation, especially after ductus arteriosus closure.

questions.text: A previously healthy 3-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department because her lips turned blue while passing stools 20 minutes ago. She has not stopped crying since then. She was born at 38 weeks' gestation. She is at the 50th percentile for length and below the 30th percentile for weight. She is alert and agitated. Her temperature is 36.6°C (98°F), pulse is 180/min, respirations are 50/min, and blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 70%, which increases to 81% on administration of 100% oxygen. Physical examination shows perioral cyanosis and retractions of the lower ribs with respiration. Cardiac examination shows a harsh grade 2/6 systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur at the left upper sternal border. Which of the following would most likely improve this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Infants with tetralogy of Fallot frequently experience tet spells, which are thought to result from spastic contractions of the hypertrophic infundibular musculature at the transition from the right ventricle to the pulmonary artery. These contractions lead to severe right outflow tract obstruction, causing increased right-to-left shunting of deoxygenated blood through the VSD. Affected infants experience severe hypoxemia and profound cyanosis during tet spells and require immediate intervention. First-line treatment includes knee-chest positioning (older children can assume a squatting position) and administration of supplemental oxygen, which acts as a pulmonary vasodilator. Knee-chest positioning increases arterial oxygenation by increasing both systemic vascular resistance and left-sided heart pressures. This, in turn, decreases right-to-left shunting across the VSD and promotes blood flow into the pulmonary circulation rather than the aorta.

Tet spells that are unresponsive to oxygen administration and knee-chest positioning are managed with IV morphine for sedation and fluids for volume expansion. If those measures fail to relieve the tet spell, IV beta blockers are administered to reduce sympathetic nervous system activity and infundibular musculature spasms.
Image Description:

Tet spells (hypercyanotic spells) are caused by a sudden decrease in systemic vascular resistance (SVR) or increase in pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR), leading to intermittent worsening of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (RVOTO) and increased right-to-left shunting. The resulting decrease in blood flow to the pulmonary circulation results in decreased blood oxygenation.

Knee-to-chest positioning or, in older children, squatting relieve symptoms by increasing SVR, which in turn reduces right-to-left-shunting and improves blood flow to the lungs.

B) INCORRECT:

Supine positioning is the recommended infant sleeping position to reduce the incidence of sudden infant death syndrome. However, supine positioning would have minimal effect on this infant's congenital cardiac defect and current cyanotic spell.

C) INCORRECT:

Hyperextension of the neck can improve tracheal compression due to vascular rings. This anatomical anomaly can sometimes manifest with respiratory distress (e.g., hypoxemia, lower rib retractions) and may be accompanied by heart murmurs (up to 50% of all affected infants also have an associated heart defect). However, the lack of any of the more classic features of tracheal and/or esophageal compression from a vascular ring anomaly, such as stridor, cough, difficulty feeding, or regurgitation, and the hyperacute onset of symptoms in this infant make this answer option less likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Elevation of the lower extremities increases venous return to the heart, which results in increased preload and cardiac output. Lower limb elevation is a useful maneuver for patients suffering from vasovagal syncope and hypovolemic shock. Although defecation can trigger vasovagal syncope, these episodes would unlikely produce central (perioral) cyanosis, as seen in this infant. Instead, this patient's systolic murmur and profound hypoxia (O2 saturation of 70 %) suggest a congenital heart condition that would be worsened by increased venous return as it would increase right-to-left ventricular shunting of deoxygenated blood.

E) INCORRECT:

Cooling of the infant's face with ice or cold water for 15–30 seconds can provoke the diving reflex to terminate paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardias. Although this infant is tachycardic, supraventricular tachycardias in infants typically manifest with nonspecific signs of heart failure (e.g., poor feeding, sweating). Also, it would not account for the patient's central cyanosis, hypoxemia, or ejection murmur.

F) INCORRECT:

Rebreathing of CO2 by breathing into a bag was formerly used for the management of hyperventilation during panic attacks. However, this technique could result in hypoxemia and is no longer recommended for the treatment of hyperventilation syndrome. Furthermore, it is unlikely that a 3-month-old infant would be having a panic attack, and her central cyanosis, severe hypoxia, and systolic murmur suggest another diagnosis.

G) INCORRECT:

Prone positioning can improve airway obstruction secondary to laryngomalacia, which seldomly causes lower rib retractions and cyanosis. Most infants with laryngomalacia, however, will have inspiratory stridor and, sometimes, reflux and feeding difficulties, all of which this patient lacks. This infant's harsh systolic murmur, central cyanosis, and profound hypoxemia are not consistent with this diagnosis.
questions.hint: Certain activities that slightly decrease oxygen saturation (e.g., defecating, crying) can trigger a cyanotic spell in patients with this congenital cardiac disease. The degree of cyanosis depends on the severity of right ventricular outflow obstruction.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravid woman at 14 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for her first prenatal visit. She reports some nausea and fatigue. She takes lithium for bipolar disorder and completed a course of clindamycin for bacterial vaginosis 12 weeks ago. She works as a teacher at a local school. She smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 12 years but stopped after finding out that she was pregnant. She does not drink alcohol. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 14-week gestation. There is mild lower extremity edema bilaterally. Urinalysis is within normal limits. The patient's child is at increased risk for developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intellectual disability in a child can be caused by a number of conditions, of which fetal alcohol syndrome is the most common. Since the syndrome is caused by maternal alcohol consumption during pregnancy and this patient does not drink alcohol, intellectual disability is unlikely to occur.

B) INCORRECT:

Ototoxicity and hearing loss are common side effects of aminoglycosides. While it has not been definitively established that maternal intake of aminoglycosides during pregnancy causes ototoxicity in the fetus, the use of aminoglycosides during pregnancy is contraindicated. Since the patient has no history of recent aminoglycoside treatment, hearing loss in the infant is not to be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Caudal regression syndrome can occur in infants with diabetic mothers and presents with malformations of the lumbosacral spine and varying degrees of motor function impairment and paralysis. Since the mother has no history of diabetes and her current urine sample is normal (glucose levels not elevated), caudal regression syndrome can be ruled out.
Image Description:

Lower abdomen and legs of a 2.5-year-old girl of a diabetic mother with poor glycemic control during pregnancy:

The hips and lower extremities appear hypoplastic and showed no muscular activity during the clinical examination. Orthopedic deformities included knees in a flexion contracture and equinovarus feet.

These findings are consistent with caudal regression syndrome. X-ray and MRI of the spine confirmed total sacral and partial lumbar vertebrae agenesis and termination of the spinal cord at T6.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's history of lithium intake as a treatment for bipolar disorder increases the risk of Ebstein anomaly in the fetus, which causes an atrialized right ventricle, tricuspid regurgitation, and right atrial enlargement. Lithium is thought to prevent physiological cardiac septation, leading to incomplete separation of the right atrioventricular valve from the ventricular myocardium (atrialization). The defect can either manifest with in utero heart failure (hydrops fetalis on ultrasound) or postnatal cyanosis, abnormal cardiac auscultation, and heart failure.
Image Description:

In the Ebstein anomaly, the tricuspid valve is displaced into the lumen of the right ventricle, resulting in atrialization of the right ventricle. The remaining ventricle is small and hypocontractile. Because tricuspid valve regurgitation is also usually present, there is retrograde flow in the right atrium, which is dilated by the volume overload, in addition to antegrade pulmonary blood flow. Blood flows through the patent foramen ovale or (commonly associated) atrial septal defect from the right atrium to the left atrium (right-to-left shunt) and then via the left ventricle into the circulation, resulting in pronounced cyanosis. The pulmonary circulation system may also be perfused through blood from the aorta (via the ductus arteriosus).

E) INCORRECT:

Fetal hydantoin syndrome is caused by maternal intake of antiepileptics during pregnancy, especially phenytoin. This patient has no history of epilepsy or treatment with anticonvulsants.

F) INCORRECT:

Intrauterine fetal bone damage and skeletal malformations can be caused by a number of conditions during pregnancy, including maternal alcohol abuse, maternal hyperparathyroidism, treatment with tetracyclines, and infections (e.g., varicella). This patient has no history of alcohol use, recent infections, or systemic disease but is on medication that has known teratogenic effects.

G) INCORRECT:

Chorioretinitis is a symptom of several congenital TORCH infections, including neonatal herpes simplex virus infections, neonatal toxoplasmosis, congenital CMV infections, and congenital varicella infections. Since the diseases are only transmitted to the fetus following maternal infection and this patient has no history of recent illness, chorioretinitis is unlikely to occur.
questions.hint: This patient is taking lithium for bipolar disorder. Especially during the first trimester, lithium intake may influence fetal development.

questions.text: A 2-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician because his mother has noticed her son has occasional bouts of "turning blue in the face" while crying. He also tires easily and sweats while feeding. He weighed 2150 g (4 lb 11 oz) at birth and has gained 200 g (7 oz). The baby appears mildly cyanotic. Examination shows a 3/6 systolic ejection murmur heard over the left upper sternal border. A single S2 is present. Echocardiography confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following factors is the main determinant of the severity of this patient's cyanosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In patients with TOF, the right ventricular outflow obstruction (RVOO) due to central pulmonary valve stenosis and hypoplasia determines cyanosis severity and systolic heart murmur intensity. The higher the degree of RVOO, the more (unoxygenated) blood will bypass pulmonary circulation and shunt straight through the VSD to the left ventricle (LV). The lower the degree of RVOO, the more blood flows through the lungs and becomes oxygenated before reaching the LV, resulting in a reduction of cyanosis. In TOF, the single S2 can result from an attenuated pulmonary component (P2) that is often not heard on auscultation.

B) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular outflow obstruction (e.g., aortic stenosis) is not one of the four features of TOF. However, if aortic stenosis (or any form of increased left ventricular outflow resistance) were present, this would decrease right-to-left shunting by creating higher left-sided pressures and thus reduce, rather than increase, cyanosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Although right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH) is one of the four features of TOF, it is not the main determinant of cyanosis. RVH is a compensatory mechanism against the outflow tract obstruction, which helps to reduce cyanosis by increasing flow through the stenotic pulmonary vasculature, so that deoxygenated blood does not flow through the VSD and into the systemic circulation. However, RVH can only compensate to a small degree to improve normal circulatory flow and is, therefore, only a minor determinant of cyanosis.

D) INCORRECT:

A ventricular septal defect (VSD) is one of the four features of TOF but it is not the main determinant of cyanosis. Rather, it is the pressure differences across the VSD that determine the degree of cyanosis. Specifically, higher right ventricular pressures and/or lower left ventricular pressures are associated with increased right-to-left shunting and, thus, with increased cyanosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Although an overriding aorta is one of the four features of TOF, it is not the main determinant of cyanosis. In patients with TOF, the aorta is displaced to the right ventricle, over the VSD, allowing blood from both ventricles to be pumped into the aorta. This causes deoxygenated blood to enter the systemic circulation, contributing to cyanosis. However, another factor has a greater impact on the degree of cyanosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Atrial septal defect (ASD) is not one of the four features of TOF. However, in a patient with TOF, the presence of a concomitant ASD could lead to greater right-to-left shunting and thus exacerbate cyanosis.
questions.hint: The presence of (intermittent) cyanosis, fatigue, and sweating during periods of exertion in a neonate with a systolic ejection murmur and a single S2 is suggestive of tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

questions.text: One day after a 4700-g (10-lb 6-oz) male newborn is delivered to a 28-year-old primigravid woman, he has bluish discoloration of his lips and fingernails. Oxygen saturation on room air is 81%. Examination shows central cyanosis. A continuous machine-like murmur is heard over the left upper sternal border. A single S2 heart sound is present. Supplemental oxygen does not improve cyanosis. Echocardiography shows the pulmonary artery arising from the posterior left ventricle and aorta arising from the right ventricle with active blood flow between the right and left ventricles. Further evaluation of the mother is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Prenatal lithium intake is associated with Ebstein anomaly, which can have a wide range of clinical presentations, including congenital cyanosis from right-to-left shunting. Depending on the severity of the anomaly, the patient may have a holosystolic murmur (due to tricuspid regurgitation), as heard in this patient. However, echocardiography would show right-sided cardiomegaly with apical displacement of the tricuspid valve and tricuspid regurgitation, not the TGA seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum TSH levels suggest hypothyroidism. Subclinical maternal hypothyroidism may increase the risk for future cognitive impairment, but it is not associated with TGA.

C) INCORRECT:

Prenatal alcohol consumption can cause fetal alcohol spectrum disorder. FASD can present with a wide range of cardiac abnormalities, including atrial septal defect, VSD, and great heart vessel defects. However, structural heart defects would also usually present with other more characteristic FASD findings, such as facial abnormalities (short palpebral fissures, thin vermillion border, smooth philtrum) and growth retardation.

D) INCORRECT:

Prenatal phenytoin intake is associated with fetal hydantoin syndrome. Although cases of congenital heart defects have been reported with maternal phenytoin use, transposition of the great arteries is rare. Furthermore, fetal hydantoin syndrome also presents with nail hypoplasia, hypoplasia of the digits, and abnormal facial features, which are all absent in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

A positive rapid plasma reagin test suggests maternal syphilis, which can infect the infant in utero. Most cases of early congenital syphilis are asymptomatic at birth and do not develop symptoms until 5 weeks of life. If symptomatic at birth, findings include hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, nasal discharge, generalized lymphadenopathy, skeletal abnormalities, and/or and pemphigus syphiliticus, none of which are present in this infant. Transposition of the great arteries is not associated with congenital syphilis.

F) CORRECT:

TGA is a cyanotic heart condition that is associated with maternal diabetes, caused by abnormal rotation of the pulmonary artery and aorta during fetal development. Mothers with untreated diabetes will have elevated fasting blood glucose levels. Other potential neonatal complications from maternal diabetes include fetal macrosomia (seen in this patient), polycythemia, hypoglycemia, hypocalcemia, and neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.
Image Description:

TGV is a cyanotic congenital heart disease in which the pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle and the aorta from the right ventricle, resulting in the formation of parallel circulatory systems. The left ventricle pumps oxygenated blood into the pulmonary circulation (red) and the right ventricle pumps deoxygenated blood into the aorta (blue), resulting in cyanosis.

TGV is fatal unless a shunt between the two circulations is present (i.e., a patent ductus arteriosus or a patent foramen ovale) or a surgical intervention is performed in the neonatal period.
questions.hint: Echocardiography showing a pulmonary artery arising from the left ventricle and aorta arising from the right ventricle confirms the diagnosis of transposition of the great arteries (TGA) which is an important cause of neonatal cyanosis that will not improve with supplemental oxygen. The continuous machine-like murmur indicates a coexistent patent ductus arteriosus, which is critical for life, as it allows mixing of oxygenated blood and its entry into the systemic circulation. Patients may also have coexistent arterial or ventricular septal defects that allow mixing of blood between the two circuits.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of nausea and fatigue. Her last menstrual period was 8 weeks ago. She has a history of bipolar disorder controlled by a drug known to sometimes cause hypothyroidism and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. A urine pregnancy test is positive. An ultrasound of the pelvis shows a viable intrauterine pregnancy. The fetus is most likely at increased risk for which of the following anomalies?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Placentation defects are associated mostly with drugs that manipulate blood flow and induce vasospasm, such as cocaine and nicotine. Lithium is not associated with this finding.

B) INCORRECT:

Aplasia cutis has been observed as a manifestation of rare congenital syndromes such as Adams-Oliver syndrome, a sequela of in-utero viral infections, and a side effect of methimazole use during pregnancy. Lithium is not associated with this finding.

C) CORRECT:

Atrialization of the right ventricle secondary to caudal displacement of a tricuspid valve leaflet is caused by Ebstein anomaly, which is strongly associated with lithium use during pregnancy, especially during the first trimester.
Image Description:

In the Ebstein anomaly, the tricuspid valve is displaced into the lumen of the right ventricle, resulting in atrialization of the right ventricle. The remaining ventricle is small and hypocontractile. Because tricuspid valve regurgitation is also usually present, there is retrograde flow in the right atrium, which is dilated by the volume overload, in addition to antegrade pulmonary blood flow. Blood flows through the patent foramen ovale or (commonly associated) atrial septal defect from the right atrium to the left atrium (right-to-left shunt) and then via the left ventricle into the circulation, resulting in pronounced cyanosis. The pulmonary circulation system may also be perfused through blood from the aorta (via the ductus arteriosus).

D) INCORRECT:

Microphthalmia can be either syndromic (in infants that also have multi-system birth defects) or isolated. Inheritance is autosomal recessive, although non-genetic causes have been identified, which include prenatal warfarin use, fetal alcohol syndrome, and viral infections. Many cases of microphthalmia are idiopathic. Lithium is not associated with this finding.

E) INCORRECT:

Neural tube defects, whether in the form of spina bifida or cephalic defects (i.e., anencephaly), have been associated with a host of comorbidities, including the use of antiepileptics (valproic acid, phenytoin, and carbamazepine), poor diabetes control, obesity, and, most prominently, folate deficiencies (either from pharmaceuticals or nutritionally). No association between lithium and neural tube defects has been demonstrated.

F) INCORRECT:

Lithium is not associated with limb deficits. Thalidomide, a drug introduced in the early 20th century to help with morning sickness, was found to be associated with severe limb defects, the extent of which was determined by how early in pregnancy the drug was started.
questions.hint: This patient is most likely taking lithium for her bipolar disorder.

questions.text: A 3-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of poor weight gain. She also reports a dusky blue discoloration to his skin during feedings and when crying. On examination, there is a harsh, systolic murmur heard over the left upper sternal border. An x-ray of the chest is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?

choices.text: Persistent connection between the aorta and pulmonary artery
Narrowing of the distal aortic arch
Anatomic reversal of aorta and pulmonary artery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A persistent connection between the aorta and pulmonary artery characterizes a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), an acyanotic heart defect that can cause cyanosis if Eisenmenger syndrome develops. However, patients with a PDA and Eisenmenger syndrome typically develop differential cyanosis because right-to-left shunting through the ductus arteriosus delivers unoxygenated blood distal to the left subclavian artery. Additionally, PDA causes a continuous, machine-like murmur heard throughout systole and diastole (unlike this patient's systolic murmur), and chest x-ray shows a prominent mediastinum caused by an enlarged pulmonary artery and aortic knob (not a boot-shaped heart).
Image Description:

In patent ductus arteriosus, there is a left-to-right shunt, with blood flowing from the aorta to the pulmonary arteries during both systole and diastole (1). This shunt leads to volume overload (recirculation) of the blood within the pulmonary vessels, the left atrium, and left ventricle (2). Eventually, because of the increased blood flow to the pulmonary circulation, pulmonary hypertension may develop as well as Eisenmenger syndrome, which involves a shunt reversal. The left-to-right-shunt without cyanosis becomes a right-to-left shunt with cyanosis (3).

Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Pink: structures that contain mixed blood

B) INCORRECT:

Hypoplasia of the left ventricle is caused by hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS), a heart condition that is typically acyanotic in the early postnatal period because a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) ensures systemic perfusion. Cyanosis develops when the PDA closes, usually within a few days of birth (not as late as 3 months as in this case). Neonates with HLHS also have weak peripheral pulses, hypotension, and metabolic acidosis as the hypoplastic left ventricle cannot maintain adequate cardiac output. Additionally, HLHS does not cause a murmur, and findings on chest x-ray are variable (e.g., small, normal, or enlarged heart and increased pulmonary venous markings) but do not include a boot-shaped heart.

C) INCORRECT:

Narrowing of the distal aortic arch, or coarctation of the aorta, manifests variably depending on the degree of aortic stenosis (AS) and the presence of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Patients with significant AS and PDA present with differential cyanosis because right-to-left shunting through the ductus arteriosus delivers unoxygenated blood distal to the left subclavian artery. Once the PDA closes (usually within a few days after birth), heart failure develops and manifests as dyspnea, sweating during feeds, and poor weight gain. Examination shows pallor (rather than cyanosis), features of inadequate left ventricular output (absent or weak femoral pulses, brachio-femoral delay), and signs of right heart failure (e.g., raised jugular venous pressure, edema, and hepatomegaly). Chest x-ray shows cardiomegaly and increased pulmonary venous markings, not a boot-shaped heart.
Image Description:

(1) Hypoplasia of aorta can lead to hypertension (↑ BP) in the head and upper limbs as well as poststenotic hypoperfusion. In patent ductus arteriosus, this can be compensated by a right-to-left-shunt of blood from the pulmonary arteries into the aorta, resulting in the flow of mixed blood with decreased oxygen saturation (↓ SaO2) to the general circulation.

(2) After closure of the ductus arteriosus, the right-to-left shunt is absent (~ SaO2) and there is hypoperfusion (↓ BP) of the abdominal organs and lower extremities with oxygenated blood.

D) CORRECT:

Right ventricular outflow obstruction (RVOO) in this patient is caused by pulmonary stenosis, which is one of the components of TOF, along with RVH, an overriding aorta, and a ventricular septal defect (VSD). Exertion, such as crying or feeding, increases the RVOO. This results in cyanosis (tet spells) due to right-to-left shunting of deoxygenated blood through the VSD instead of the pulmonary valve, which in turn causes the murmur to become softer. The right ventricle hypertrophies because it chronically pumps against high resistance caused by the RVOO.

Older children with TOF tend to squat during a tet spell. Squatting increases systemic vascular resistance, which increases left ventricular pressure and decreases the right-to-left shunting of blood through the VSD. Infants who are having a tet spell should be placed with their knees toward their chest to achieve the same effect.
Image Description:

Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)

The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

E) INCORRECT:

Anatomic reversal of the aorta and pulmonary artery is known as transposition of the great vessels (TGV). This condition causes cyanosis because the aorta arises from the right ventricle and thus results in systemic circulation of deoxygenated blood. However, unlike this patient, cyanosis in TGV manifests immediately after birth. Additionally, chest x-ray in TGV shows an egg-on-a-string appearance due to an enlarged heart with a narrowed mediastinum, which resembles an egg lying on its side.
Image Description:

In transposition of the great vessels, deoxygenated blood enters the systemic circulation. Survival after birth is only possible via an intracardiac shunt (e.g., across a patent ductus arteriosus and/or a patent foramen ovale). The shunt diverts oxygenated blood from the pulmonary circulation into the systemic circulation (white arrows).

F) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation (TR) in infants is usually due to a malformed and displaced tricuspid valve in Ebstein anomaly. These infants may develop cyanosis only if there's an associated ASD or PFO that allows for right-to-left shunting of blood. Auscultation would reveal a holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border, like in this patient, with a widely split S2. However, a chest x-ray in Ebstein anomaly will show right atrial enlargement (due to chronic reflux of blood from the right ventricle into the right atrium) - not a boot-shaped heart as seen in this infant.
Image Description:

In the Ebstein anomaly, the tricuspid valve is displaced into the lumen of the right ventricle, resulting in atrialization of the right ventricle. The remaining ventricle is small and hypocontractile. Because tricuspid valve regurgitation is also usually present, there is retrograde flow in the right atrium, which is dilated by the volume overload, in addition to antegrade pulmonary blood flow. Blood flows through the patent foramen ovale or (commonly associated) atrial septal defect from the right atrium to the left atrium (right-to-left shunt) and then via the left ventricle into the circulation, resulting in pronounced cyanosis. The pulmonary circulation system may also be perfused through blood from the aorta (via the ductus arteriosus).
questions.hint: The boot-shaped heart on this boy's x-ray is caused by right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH). His harsh, systolic murmur heard over the left upper sternal border is caused by pulmonary stenosis. These findings, along with his acute hypoxic spells (which cause cyanosis), indicate a diagnosis of tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

questions.text: A previously healthy 2-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department because her lips turned blue while passing stools 30 minutes ago. She is at the 40th percentile for length and below the 35th percentile for weight. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 65%, which increases to 76% on administration of 100% oxygen. Physical examination shows perioral cyanosis and retractions of the lower ribs with respiration. Cardiac examination shows a harsh grade 2/6 systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard best at the left upper sternal border. Which of the following is most likely to improve this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cooling of the infant's face with ice or cold water for 15–30 seconds can provoke the diving reflex to terminate paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardias. Supraventricular tachycardias in infants typically manifest with nonspecific signs of heart failure (e.g., poor feeding, sweating) and would not account for the patient's central cyanosis, hypoxemia, or ejection murmur.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevation of the lower extremities increases venous return to the heart, which results in increased preload and cardiac output. Lower limb elevation is a useful maneuver for patients suffering from vasovagal syncope and hypovolemic shock. Although defecation can trigger vasovagal syncope, these episodes would unlikely produce central (perioral) cyanosis, as seen in this infant. Increased venous return and the subsequent increase in right-to-left ventricular shunting of deoxygenated blood would worsen this patient's condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Administration of indomethacin is used to treat patent ductus arteriosus. PDA presents with a continuous machine-like murmur, not a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur, as heard in this patient. Infants with PDA are typically acyanotic at presentation, but eventually Eisenmenger reaction may result in shunt reversal and differential cyanosis. Indomethacin will not improve this patient's condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperextension of the neck can improve tracheal compression due to vascular rings. This anatomical anomaly can sometimes present as respiratory distress (hypoxemia, lower rib retractions) and may be accompanied by heart murmurs; up to 50% of affected infants also have an associated heart defect, as seen here. However, this infant lacks classic features of tracheal and/or esophageal compression from a vascular ring anomaly, such as stridor, cough, difficulty feeding, or regurgitation, and hyperacute onset of symptoms. Hyperextension of the neck will not improve this patient's condition.

E) CORRECT:

Infants with tetralogy of Fallot frequently suffer from tet spells, which are most likely due to spastic contractions of the hypertrophic infundibular musculature at the transition from the right ventricle to the pulmonary artery. This contraction results in severe right outflow tract obstruction, causing increased right-to-left shunting of deoxygenated blood through the VSD. Affected infants present with severe hypoxemia and profound cyanosis. First-line treatments for tet spells include knee-chest positioning (older children can assume a squatting position) and administration of supplemental oxygen (acts as a pulmonary vasodilator). Knee-chest positioning increases arterial oxygenation via increased systemic vascular resistance and thus left-sided heart pressures. This, in turn, decreases right-to-left shunting across the VSD and promotes blood flow into the pulmonary circulation rather than the aorta.
Image Description:

Tet spells (hypercyanotic spells) are caused by a sudden decrease in systemic vascular resistance (SVR) or increase in pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR), leading to intermittent worsening of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (RVOTO) and increased right-to-left shunting. The resulting decrease in blood flow to the pulmonary circulation results in decreased blood oxygenation.

Knee-to-chest positioning or, in older children, squatting relieve symptoms by increasing SVR, which in turn reduces right-to-left-shunting and improves blood flow to the lungs.

F) INCORRECT:

Prone positioning can improve airway obstruction secondary to laryngomalacia, which can cause lower rib retractions and cyanosis in rare cases. Most infants with laryngomalacia will instead have an inspiratory stridor and, sometimes, reflux and feeding difficulties, all of which this patient lacks. This infant's harsh systolic murmur, central cyanosis, and profound hypoxemia are not consistent with this diagnosis.
questions.hint: Right ventricular outflow obstruction is a significant feature of this common congenital cardiac defect. Certain activities that slightly decrease oxygen saturation (e.g., defecating, crying) can acutely worsen the right ventricular outflow obstruction, triggering a cyanotic spell.

questions.text: Shortly after delivery, a female newborn develops bluish discoloration of the lips, fingers, and toes. She was born at term to a 38-year-old primigravid woman. Pregnancy was complicated by maternal diabetes mellitus. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 81%. Echocardiography shows immediate bifurcation of the vessel arising from the left ventricle; the vessel emerging from the right ventricle gives out coronary, head, and neck vessels. An abnormality in which of the following developmental processes most likely accounts for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Separation of tricuspid valve tissue from myocardium
Division of aorta and pulmonary artery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Failed separation of tricuspid valve tissue from myocardium causes Ebstein anomaly. Mild apical displacement is often asymptomatic, whereas individuals with marked tricuspid valve leaflet displacement and incompetence can present with cyanosis due to right-to-left shunting (interatrial) and poor oxygen saturation, as observed in this patient. However, echocardiography would show apical displacement of the septal tricuspid valve leaflet, not transposition of the great vessels.
Image Description:

In the Ebstein anomaly, the tricuspid valve is displaced into the lumen of the right ventricle, resulting in atrialization of the right ventricle. The remaining ventricle is small and hypocontractile. Because tricuspid valve regurgitation is also usually present, there is retrograde flow in the right atrium, which is dilated by the volume overload, in addition to antegrade pulmonary blood flow. Blood flows through the patent foramen ovale or (commonly associated) atrial septal defect from the right atrium to the left atrium (right-to-left shunt) and then via the left ventricle into the circulation, resulting in pronounced cyanosis. The pulmonary circulation system may also be perfused through blood from the aorta (via the ductus arteriosus).

B) INCORRECT:

Impaired fusion of the endocardial cushion can cause atrial septal defect, ventricular septal defect, or atrioventricular septal defects, all of which are usually asymptomatic at birth. Infants with complete atrioventricular septal defects can present with symptoms of heart failure. Untreated, these defects can cause significant pulmonary hypertension and reversal of the left-to-right shunt (Eisenmenger syndrome). However, early cyanosis is not typical and echocardiography will show the respective septal defect, not transposition of the great vessels.
Image Description:

A defect in the ventricular septum leads to a left-to-right shunt, the volume of which is dependent on the size of the defect. Blood flows from the left ventricle to the right ventricle (white arrow) along the pressure gradient (1). This leads to increased RV and LV preload (due to increased end-diastolic volume), ventricular hypertrophy and dilation (double-headed white arrows), and pulmonary hypertension resulting from excessive pulmonary blood flow (2). In end-stage disease, the pressure gradient is reversed because of Eisenmenger syndrome (shunt reversal), leading to the flow of mixed blood to the systemic circulation (white arrow) and subsequent cyanosis (3).

Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

C) INCORRECT:

Anterosuperior displacement of the infundibular septum is one of the features in tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) that causes infundibular pulmonary stenosis, TOF's key prognostic determinant. Infants with TOF can present with early cyanosis and poor oxygen saturation, as observed in this newborn. However, echocardiography would show the presence of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction and hypertrophy, overriding aorta, and ventricular septal defect, not transposition of the great vessels.
Image Description:

Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)

The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

D) INCORRECT:

Failed development of a septum dividing the aorta and pulmonary artery causes persistent truncus arteriosus. In patients with truncus arteriosus, a common trunk arises from both the right and left ventricle, mixing arterial and venous blood. Infants will present with early cyanosis and poor oxygen saturation, as observed in this patient. However, echocardiography will show a single overriding vessel connected to both ventricles, not transposition of the great vessels.

E) CORRECT:

In the development of the cardiac outflow tract, neural crest and endocardial cells migrate to form truncal ridges and bulbar ridges from the truncus arteriosus and bulbus cordis, respectively. Normally, the truncal and bulbar ridges spiral and fuse to form the aorticopulmonary septum (AP septum), which further develops into the ascending aorta and pulmonary trunk. Transposition of the great vessels (TGV) occurs when the aorticopulmonary septum fails to spiral. Infants born to mothers with diabetes are at increased risk of developing TGV.

TGV is incompatible with life unless mixing occurs via an intracardiac shunt across a patent foramen ovale, ventricle septal defect, or atrial septal defect, or via an extracardiac connection (e.g., patent ductus arteriosus).
Image Description:

I: Development of the muscular interventricular septum and interventricular foramen
- The primary ventricle is a single cavity that is separated from the atrial cavity by the endocardial cushion. Ventricular septation begins with the formation of a muscular interventricular septum, which arises from the floor of the primitive ventricle and grows cranially toward the endocardial cushion. The interventricular foramen is the space between the endocardial cushion and the growing edge of the muscular interventricular septum and it allows for interventricular communication.

II: Development of the aorticopulmonary septum
- The aorticopulmonary septum develops from ridges of tissue derived from neural crest cells within the ventricular outflow tract (truncus arteriosus). These ridges are continuous with the bulbar ridges of the bulbar cordis (not shown here).

III: Development of the membranous interventricular septum and closure of the interventricular foramen
- The membranous interventricular septum develops from the bulbar ridges and the endocardial cushion.
- The caudal end of the aorticopulmonary septum fuses with the muscular interventricular septum and closes the interventricular foramen.

IV: Division of the ventricular outflow tract
- The aorticopulmonary septum fuses and rotates 180°, dividing the outflow tract into the aorta (from the left ventricle) and pulmonary trunk (from the right ventricle).
questions.hint: Echocardiography shows the pulmonary trunk arising (posteriorly) from the left ventricle, and the aorta (which gives out coronary, head, and neck arteries) arising (anteriorly) from the right ventricle, which is called transposition of the great vessels. Early cyanosis and poor oxygen saturation are consistent with this diagnosis.

questions.text: Several hours after vaginal delivery, a male newborn delivered at full-term develops tachycardia and tachypnea. His blood pressure is within normal limits. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 80%. Physical examination shows cyanosis, supraclavicular and intercostal retractions, and a machine-like murmur over the precordium. Bedside echocardiography shows pulmonary and systemic circulation are in parallel rather than in series. What is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sildenafil, a phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitor, is used to dilate pulmonary vessels in neonates with pulmonary hypertension until the underlying cause is addressed. In this patient, dilation of pulmonary vessels could decrease right to left shunting across the PDA and, thus, worsen his symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

Alprostadil (prostaglandin E1) is used in newborns with congenital heart defects to maintain a patent ductus arteriosus. In this infant, who has transposition of the great vessels, only deoxygenated blood is pumped from the right ventricle into the aorta. Therefore, it is important that oxygenated and deoxygenated blood are mixed through a shunt flow until definitive treatment (e.g., surgery) is performed. Other ductal-dependent heart defects include tetralogy of Fallot, critical pulmonic stenosis, and pulmonary atresia.

C) INCORRECT:

Beta blockers, such as propranolol and metoprolol, are used for the treatment of neonatal hypertension and congenital long QT syndrome. In this patient, tachycardia is a compensatory mechanism and thus should not be treated with beta blockers.

D) INCORRECT:

Indomethacin, an inhibitor of prostaglandin synthesis, is used to close a patent ductus arteriosus in premature infants. In patients with transposition of the great vessels, survival depends on communication between the two parallel circulations. Hence, closure of the patent ductus arteriosus would have a deleterious effect in this infant.

E) INCORRECT:

Dopamine can be used to raise systemic blood pressure in infants with cardiogenic shock. This infant does not need a vasopressor as he is not hypotensive.
questions.hint: The findings of cyanosis early in a neonate's life are concerning for a congenital heart defect. This patient's echocardiogram shows two separate circulations connected by a patent ductus arteriosus (machine-like murmur). This indicates transposition of the great vessels.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with tachycardia, diaphoresis, lightheadedness, and chest pressure. On initial evaluation in the ambulance, she had a heart rate of 210 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 92/58 mm Hg. Her oxygen saturation was 88% with ambient air and did not increase with supplemental oxygen.
Shortly after arrival in the emergency department, her tachycardia spontaneously resolves. Physical examination reveals a markedly elevated jugular venous pressure, splitting of the first and second heart sounds, a third heart sound, a 3/6 holosystolic murmur over the lower sternal border, and digital clubbing.
An electrocardiogram is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cyanotic congenital heart conditions — including tetralogy of Fallot, transposition of the great vessels, and truncus arteriosus — usually become clinically manifest in early childhood.

B) INCORRECT:

Amyloidosis and sarcoidosis are infiltrative cardiomyopathies and do not cause right-to-left intracardiac shunting.

C) INCORRECT:

Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy, which involves fibrofatty replacement of the right ventricular myocardium, can manifest as right heart failure, ventricular tachyarrhythmias, or sudden cardiac death; it is not associated with supraventricular arrhythmias or right-to-left shunting.

D) CORRECT:

Cyanotic congenital heart conditions — including tetralogy of Fallot, transposition of the great vessels, and truncus arteriosus — usually become clinically manifest in early childhood. However, Ebstein anomaly (ventricular displacement of the tricuspid valve, resulting in a regurgitant or stenotic valve and a small right ventricle) may not become evident until adulthood, when the patient presents with a supraventricular arrhythmia. In 80% of affected patients, an interatrial communication (i.e., patent foramen ovale or atrial septal defect) is present, permitting right-to-left shunting of blood. The murmur in this case represents tricuspid regurgitation. The clubbing in this patient is suggestive of chronic hypoxemia.

About 20% of patients with Ebstein anomaly also have ventricular preexcitation — the Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome — with an accessory electrical pathway between the atrium and ventricle. Electrocardiographic evidence of a delta wave and short PR interval suggests that the Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome is the cause of the patient’s tachycardia. In patients with a supraventricular arrhythmia, it is important to evaluate for an underlying cardiac structural etiology.

Key learning point: Ebstein anomaly is a congenital heart condition that may manifest in adulthood with clinical features including electrocardiographic abnormalities such as supraventricular arrhythmias or ventricular preexcitation.

E) INCORRECT:

Amyloidosis and sarcoidosis are infiltrative cardiomyopathies and do not cause right-to-left intracardiac shunting.

questions.text:
A 7-day-old male infant is brought to the emergency department by his mother for evaluation of poor feeding. He was born full term and had no complications at birth. All of his mother's prenatal laboratory results were normal. He is breastfed, but his mother is considering switching him to a bottle because he appears to tire quickly during feeds and has not gained weight since hospital discharge. Today his mother tried to feed him with a bottle, but he has not been interested in eating since this afternoon and has had fewer wet diapers than usual.
On examination, he is afebrile and has a heart rate of 170 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 74 breaths per minute, and a blood pressure of 69/35 mm Hg in the upper right extremity. A pulse oximeter, placed on his right palm, reads 78% while he breathes ambient air. His tone is low, and he appears cyanotic. Capillary refill is 4 seconds.
An intravenous line is placed, and a series of laboratory tests are ordered.
Which one of the following medications is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has typical findings of cardiogenic shock. Given the time course of the presentation, he should be considered to have a ductal-dependent lesion, such as hypoplastic left heart syndrome, until proven otherwise. Neonates with a ductal-dependent cardiac lesion may present with central cyanosis, tachypnea, and failure to return to their birth weight.
